Chandra Bhat, Brian Chase, Bill Foster, Hyejoo Kang, Jim Maclachlan, Kiyomi Seiya, Phillip Varghese, Dave Wildman

page.title:
Fast Recycler Stacking
Fast Recycler Stacking
page.enlisting:
• Method of longitudinal stacking – Increases charge density in Booster batches by – May allow more batches stacked in MI – Will allow early tests of MI at higher beam currents • Uses broadband “Arbitrary Waveform” RF system – Exists in RR; planned for longitudinal dampers in MI • Advantages WRT Slip Stacking: – No emittance growth (in principle) – No problems with Beam Loading (debunched beams) • Method of longitudinal stacking
• Method of longitudinal stacking
– Increases charge density in Booster batches by

– May allow more batches stacked in MI – Will allow early tests of MI at higher beam currents • Uses broadband “Arbitrary Waveform” RF system – Exists in RR; planned for longitudinal dampers in MI

page.title:
First Tests in Recycler
First Tests in Recycler
page.enlisting:
• Recycler already has 2000V Arbitrary Waveform RF system, with controls • Recycler does not have extraneous cavities (2.5 MHz, 7.5 MHz and 53 MHz) which might resonate up (“beam loading”) and destroy the beam RF structure. 1. Debunch beam in MI 2. Compress the beam in Recycler 3. Transfer back to MI 4. Rebunch and Accelerate (…not done) • Recycler already has 2000V Arbitrary Waveform RF system, with controls
• Recycler already has 2000V Arbitrary
Waveform RF system, with controls
• Recycler does not have extraneous cavities (2.5 MHz, 7.5 MHz and 53 MHz) which might resonate up (“beam loading”) and destroy the beam RF structure.
• Recycler does not have extraneous cavities
(2.5 MHz, 7.5 MHz and 53 MHz) which
might resonate up (“beam loading”) and
destroy the beam RF structure.

page.title:
Remaining Tasks for RR Tests
Remaining Tasks for RR Tests
page.enlisting:
• Understand Stacking Scientifically – Quantify emittance growth – Understand incoming beam properties • Optimize Tuning – Push to higher currents – Compress Multiple Batches – Simulation work to recognize mis-tunings • Understand Stacking Scientifically
• Understand Stacking Scientifically
– Quantify emittance growth – Understand incoming beam properties

• Optimize Tuning
• Optimize Tuning

page.title:
First Test in Main Injector (December 12)
First Test in Main Injector
(December 12)
page.enlisting:
• Patched together a 500 V barrier-bucket system in the Main Injector – “Green Bomb” (old broadband cavity in MI) – Spare Recycler Power Amplifier – Swiped arbitrary Waveform from Recycler • Debunch beam in MI – Actually this is easier than transferring beam • Patched together a 500 V barrier-bucket

page.title:
2.5 MHZ Transient Beam Loading Waveforms (GPJ)
2.5 MHZ Transient Beam
Loading Waveforms (GPJ)
page.enlisting:
• Adiabatic Coalescing requires 200~500V • Easy to generate with broadband system • 2.5MHz Transient Beam Loading Voltages larger → Reinstall Cavity shorts on 2.5 MHz cavities (Jan.)

page.title:
MI Hardware Tasks • Dedicated Broadband System in MI
MI Hardware Tasks
• Dedicated Broadband System in MI
page.enlisting:
– Green Bomb & spare RR amp – Switch to Damper amps and cavities long term – Need dedicated Arbitrary Waveform module • Cavity Shorts on 53 MHz cavities (installed) • Cavity shorts on 2.5 MHz cavities (Jan.) • LLRF work for Debunching/paraphasing • Damper able to control Coupled-Bunch
– Green Bomb & spare RR amp
– Switch to Damper amps and cavities long term
– Need dedicated Arbitrary Waveform module
• Cavity Shorts on 53 MHz cavities (installed)
• Cavity shorts on 2.5 MHz cavities (Jan.)
